node.title: 'Cutting-edge' project to extract water from air in the outback. But is it safe?
node.alt: A large road sign up close, one end pointing to Tennant Creek, the other to Darwin
node.description: A small town in the Territory outback will play host to a new technology that sucks water from the atmosphere to create hydrogen – and the government is backing it with action.
node.content:
["In the centre of Australia, where the landscape is parched and temperatures can soar into the high 40s, water can be a precious commodity.", "But a \"cutting edge\" technology is being trialled in the Northern Territory, giving a glimpse of how water-dependent industries may one day be able to operate in the outback without having to rely on sucking those resources from underneath the earth.", "The Desert Bloom Hydrogen project has been heralded as \"ground-breaking\" by the NT government, for its technological ability to extract water from the atmosphere to create hydrogen.", "\"It is absolutely cutting edge, at the forefront of technology at the moment,\" NT Energy Minister Eva Lawler said.", "\"[But] it's something that could be used into the future.", "", "
The humidity often hovers at 20 or 30 per cent in Tennant Creek.\u00a0(ABC RN:\u00a0Stefan Fergueca)
", "The full extent of this technology's long-term environmental impact remains somewhat unknown, but a study into any potential dangers is weeks away from being released.", "The project in Tennant Creek is being fast-tracked by the Territory government and has been granted Major Project Status.", "The government said the project has already been backed by a private firm, Sanguine Impact Investment, to the tune of $1 billion, to get it off the ground.", "Emeritus professor Barry Hart, a Victorian-based water expert who was previously involved in the NT's fracking inquiry\u00a0and has long-term knowledge of the NT's climate conditions, said the project was \"unique\" and a first of its kind in Australia.", "\"The energy for this project comes from solar, it's all solar, so it's nothing off the grid. And the water, uniquely, is going to come from the atmosphere,\" Professor Hart said.", "\"You're not looking at domestic water, or groundwater, or seawater, it's water coming from the atmosphere.\"\u00a0", "
So how on earth does it work?
", "The desert may seem like a dry place, but Professor Hart said the relative humidity in Tennant Creek \u2014 \"the amount of moisture that's in the atmosphere\" \u2014 was often up to 20 or 30 per cent.", "\"Given the volume of air, that's still a large amount of water,\" he said.", "The process of extracting the water, Professor Hart explained, was a \"pretty simple one, conceptually\".", "\"The air is drawn through a column, that water is absorbed on the column, and the columns that will be used \u2026 have characteristics that they can absorb water at lower temperatures,\" he said.", "\"If you then heat it up to the order of 150 degrees [Celsius], it will evaporate the water that's been trapped, and that can be condensed, and then taken off to the electrolytic cell, and hydrogen [is] produced.\"", "
Are there dangers involved?
", "", "
The project would use solar power to draw water from the air\u00a0and produce hydrogen through electrolysis.(ABC RN:\u00a0Stefan Fergueca)
", "Professor Hart has commissioned a study by an air quality modelling organisation to determine any potential dangers posed by the project.", "\"I suppose the potential risk is that you suck all of the water out of a relatively low humidity [area], and leave that with, potentially, damage to the environment and maybe even to humans,\" he said.", "The firm behind the Desert Bloom Hydrogen project, Aqua Aerem, has flagged its plans to begin mass-producing and exporting hydrogen overseas to Asian markets within five years.", "Aqua Aerem co-founder and CEO Gerard Reiter said the project offered \"the most direct, cost-effective route to Asian export markets\".", "Construction on the project is scheduled to start next year, with production to begin in 2023."]
